summary: Axis network cameras allow remote code execution due to insufficient sanitisation of the action parameter.
Axis Camera Station and device firmware vulnerable to directory traversal allowing arbitrary file read.
Axis 206/207 series cameras have default credentials that permit administrative access over HTTP.
Hikvision cameras and NVRs suffer from a command injection vulnerability in the web server component.
Hikvision devices expose backdoor credentials allowing unauthenticated remote access.
Dahua cameras allow remote command execution via crafted ONVIF requests.
Ubiquiti UniFi Video cameras vulnerable to authentication bypass on the management API.
Ubiquiti Edge devices allow remote code execution through crafted HTTP requests.
Reolink IP cameras allow authentication bypass via predictable session tokens.
Amcrest cameras expose telnet interface with hardcoded credentials allowing root access.
Multiple Dahua OEM products allow remote command execution due to improper authentication.
Hanwha Techwin Wisenet devices allow stack-based buffer overflow via crafted HTTP request.
Grandstream cameras contain hidden telnet backdoor credentials enabling full compromise.
Vivotek cameras allow remote command injection through crafted CGI parameters.
Vivotek firmware permits credential disclosure via predictable session tokens.
Uniview devices vulnerable to authentication bypass in web management interface.
Uniview NVR allows remote code execution via crafted RPC call.
Lorex and Dahua OEM devices allow authentication bypass and remote command execution.
Foscam cameras vulnerable to stack overflow via RTSP DESCRIBE command.
D-Link DCS-2530L and DCS-2670L cameras expose an unauthenticated /config/getuser endpoint that returns the administrator password.
Shenzhen Hichip IP cameras (firmware V11.4.8.1.1-20170926) have an input validation flaw allowing a crafted multicast packet to trigger a denial-of-service.
Milesight Video Management System (VMS) 40.7.0.79-r1 and earlier fail to properly sanitize HTTP input; an unauthenticated attacker can send a crafted request to crash the server (remote DoS).
TP-Link Tapo C310 cameras (firmware 1.3.0) use hardcoded RTSP credentials allowing any network user to view the live video feed without authentication.
TP-Link Tapo C200 V1 cameras suffer an access-control flaw: an attacker with physical UART access can halt the boot loader and set init=/bin/sh to gain root access.

OpenHarmony OS (used in some smart cameras) up to v3.1.1 has an authentication bypass in its multimedia subsystem; a LAN attacker can bypass permission checks and gain full control of the camera service.
ABUS TVIP 20000-21150 cameras allow remote code execution by injecting shell metacharacters into the /cgi-bin/mft/wireless_mft field of an HTTP request.
CP-Plus DVRs have an improper input validation bug in the web interface; an unauthenticated attacker can send a crafted HTTP request to change the system time (DoS effect).
Bosch IP cameras contain a command injection vulnerability where an authenticated administrator can inject OS commands via unsanitized input to execute arbitrary code.
The Imou GO (Dahua) Android app v1.0.11 has a flaw in its DownloadFirmwareService allowing forced download of arbitrary files without integrity checks to device storage.
FLIR AX8 thermal sensor cameras (firmware â‰¤1.46.16) are vulnerable to directory traversal; an unauthenticated remote attacker can upload a malicious symbolic link to obtain sensitive files.
D-Link DCS-8300LHV2 IP cameras have an ONVIF SetSystemDateAndTime command injection where an adjacent-network attacker can craft a malicious sch:TZ XML element to execute arbitrary commands as root.
Axis Camera Station Pro has a privilege-escalation bug: a non-admin user can gain SYSTEM privileges by exploiting an improper file deletion redirect during service restart.
Axis Camera Station (Windows client) leaks sensitive credentials in its Incident Report feature; if enabled, stored passwords may be accessible due to insufficient access control.
Axis Camera Station Pro allows an authenticated user to edit or delete camera views without proper server-side permission checks.
Axis Camera Station (Pro) audit log tampering: an authenticated client can inject malicious entries to corrupt the audit log or crash the Camera Station server, causing a denial-of-service.
